Around the internet you'll see some people comparing Singularity to Half-Life 2 and Bioshock, so I'll compare too, but I'll show what points those games has in common with Singularity, so you can form your own opinion.

Story

You play as captain Nathaniel Renko, who comes to a misterious island called Katorga-12 after the military has received some signs of radiation while its radar was passing by the Eastern Russia; when you arrive at the island, it is a desolate place, abandoned long ago for unknown reasons, while some kind of military reasearch has gone completely wrong when the russians discovered a new element called E-99.

Gameplay

Some people say that this desolated island has some resemblance with Bioshock's rapture or even Half-Life 2's City 17, because of the abandoned post-apocalyptic feel it has; but Katorga-12 has its own charm, you can think it as a second Chernobyl (if you played the Stalker series you'll know what I'm talking about). People who used to live there abandoned their normal lives for good, leaving papers on the tables, schools are full of children drawnings and kitchens are still filled with canned food and pots. It's a wonderful game, full of places to explore and learn about what happened in the island, and Singularity really rewards exploration, so please, don't rush while playing this game, take your time because you'll be rewarded with secrets that only the devs at Raven could have done so well. Most of the plot is explained by notes you find scattered around the buildings and audio logs. Some are well hidden, requiring even a bit of thinking before you can reach them, which I myself think it's just awesome. This is a feature that you'll find in Bioshock, but in Singularity I find it particularly better, because the voice acting is just perfect (at the beggining of the game you'll hear some audio logs made by the children themselves, trust me, it'll give you some chills). There is a couple more features that will bring Bioshock to mind, for instance the way you collect items in the game: you must interact with them pressing a key, only ammo you can actually pick up running above them; the health system isn't regenerative as in most shooters, you must collect aid packs to use later pressing another key, as with Bioshock.

Singularity has kind of the same pace as Bioshock, that is having you searching the place for clues, secrets and items, then entering in some fire-fights. During the action scenes you can use a very well selected variety of weapons, and it doesn't limit itself with the everyday shotgun and machine gun: you have weapons that let you literaly guide the bullet, and even a grenade launcher that let you drive" the grenade around the environment; even the usual sniper rifle has a feature that let you slow down time to aim well at your targets. Unlike in Bioshock

reviewText: I have been a long time fan of Raven Software ever since discovering Jedi Knight 2 when I was a wee 9th grader. Last year's Wolfenstein was a bit tedious after you got into the meat of the game, yet was still quite entertaining to me. Starting Singularity, I was immediately captivated and interested in where the story was heading, invoking a cheesy albeit charming science-fiction-B-movie feel. The pacing is great and the game mechanics heavily remind me of a hybrid of Half-Life 2 and Bioshock. I was honestly taken aback by how much I liked this game, though the $50 pricetag is steep for a June 2010 release (I bought it in October for the full $60!). I say it was still worth it though, they deserve my money, they did quite well!

Let me preface this review by saying I waited 4 years to play this game. I liked the look of it when it released in 2010 but could never bring myself to buy it at full price. I picked it up on sale from Steam for about $8 and for that price is it probably worth it.

The Singularity isn't a bad game in any way but it relies to much on being derivative of it's peers and often makes the classic modern FPS mistake of using a brown color pallet and heavy industrial level design.

The shooting itself is good if not great, the enemies are varied (shades of Doom, Wolfenstein, Half Life and even COD can be seen here) and weapons and your TMD (read Half life 2 gravity gun mix with some other stuff) can be upgraded. Towards the end of the game you can do some really neat things with your TMD/weapon combos that keep combat fun and lively.

The story is a little convoluted and the characters are muddy. Much like the TMD rips off Half Life 2's gravity gun in some respects so the cast here are retreads of the characters in the older game. The female lead is a poor man's Alyx Vance but does a serviceable job guiding you through the story. I just had a hard time connecting with the characters, although I will say the multiple endings to the game is a nice touch!

The TMD does also allow for some minor puzzle elements that can initially seem taxing but once you have seen one of about the 3 or 4 puzzles that are used through the game you can quickly identify and solve them. In the end what strikes you as an “oh wow nice touch” trick the first time ends up feeling played about by the 25th.

This leads me onto my biggest gripe with the game: the level design. The Singularity has some amazing potential and wastes it utterly with brown industrial environ after brown industrial environ. The levels set in the past are, varied, bright, colorful and full of unique little touches that made me want to explore this cold war era lab (it really reminded me of half life 1, a living breathing facility I wanted to inhabit not just visit). It is a crying shame that you never visit them for more than 10 minutes at a time. These levels are also filled with Russian soliders that act half way intelligently and are fun to fight. The modern levels by contrast are by the numbers brown boxes that remind me of quake 1 or painkiller with less character. The enemies that inhabit them are varied and some are fun to fight but too many simply charge at you. Once you acquire some decent weapons and TMD upgrades they become a chore to fight.

The split between old and modern sums up the Singularity well for every good moment there is something dull and bland. A unique feature or moment here is followed by a dull 30 minute sepia section shortly after. If only Raven had stuck to using the 50's setting throughout the game we may have had a truly unique and classic game on our hands. It's still a decent shooter and well worth a blast through if you can get it for under $10 but I came away feeling happy I played it but sad that it wasn't as good as it could have been.

Now this is a nice suprise a bargain on steam at the time I got this game. I read a lot about this game. Like there is a huge budget for this game and there were worries that it wouldn't sell that well.

The story
The game is about a secret Soviet weapon that has been fueled by an element called E99. That can be used to temper with time on a very local scale. It is travelling foreward and backwards in time that eventually clears the reasons and causes of all the troubles and combat you are in. There are some good suprises in the story and some very good shock and awe" moments. I really enjoyed it all I must admit. I couldn't really stop playing till the end of the story and thus the game.

The theme "time travel" always fascinated me from the time I saw the movie and read the book Time Machine by Orson Wells. So that of time travel is a very big plus or pro for me.

Way of telling
The story telling is being done with ocassional cutscenes that reminded me of Call Of Duty in a way. You start out with a search of a secret Soviet base on an remote island close to the Russian border. You search the base or island I must say for clues what happened in the past and why there such strange mutated creatures roaming around the island? This gave me the feeling of the game Stalker where a nuclear accident also created strange mutations among the wildlife or even to the human inhabitants. Ocassionally you see ghosts from the past acting out scenes of mayhem that happened years ago. Those scenes reminded me of the game FEAR somehow. Where you also had flashbacks via ghostly like scenes. That sented chills down my spine.

Film and sound footage
The story is good and even backed up with some very amusing films and sound footage that have been scattered around the base. Those recordings you can listen to or even see in film projectors still functioning at the base. Most of the time the have that eerie looking sound or damaged footage of aging of some other violent event.

Graphics and sounds
The graphics are superb and the sounds are very well done. Although the story is very amusing to say the least. It also makes the maps a little linear in a way. There is no free roaming around the maps like you can with so many roleplaying games. But do not let that spoil the fun. There are still plenty of places to search for loot like ammo and the E99 fuel metals.

You have to find certain characters in the game. Get this tool or this element find it take it somewhere and all backed up by a more or less logical story line. Do I recommend it? Oh yes you should try this game if you like the elements of timetravel and some scary horror moments in a game.

A game for mature players
So I must add this game is for the mature players that like some gory scenes from time to time. There are a lot of dead corpses  some even impaled (like in games like Doom) and bloodbaths. When you shoot enemies they lose limps and other body parts by the impact of the bullets. There is even an time weapon where you can "age" people very fast.

A very good game & get it if you can
So be warned or informed what ever you like. This is a good well done game. You can see there has been put a lot of effort in this game. So I do recommend this game. Go for it if you like the things mentioned above."

I'd say that Singularity is underrated considering I've not heard much about it; I decided to buy it during the summer sale.  It took me about 8 hours to complete and I enjoyed the gameplay. I was probably about two hours in before the game picked up so if you're feeling bored at first, don't be too discouraged to continue on. You're given the Time Distortion Device and are able to upgrade it throughout the game. The TMD lets you solve puzzles and perform combination attacks on enemies. The combat was fun and the boss fights were also fun; you're given at least a couple options for killing things so it is entertaining in that aspect. There are notes to read and audio logs to listen to throughout the game that will help fill in the story.\n\nI enjoyed the audio and the graphics were decent but consider that this game was made in 2010 so the visuals aren't just awesome. There is no anti-aliasing setting in the game's options but you can simply override that in the NVIDIA Control Panel and it should work. I likely won't replay the game since I read everything the first time through, but it was worth the sale price.
Beat the game in about 8 hours.  I would never pay $30 for the game but if you can get it on sale for $10 or less then I would say it is totally worth it!

Short Answer

Should you buy it - $30 is a little bit much for a four year old game but it is a good game and if you really like FPS's, Yes
Should you buy it on sale - Absolutely

Long Answer

Singularity is a standard FPS with just a little bit more that sets it above the norm.

Visuals : The visuals in the game wont destroy your graphics card or anything but it does tax it a little bit. The scenery and set pieces look very nice, sometimes really pretty. There is no reuse of areas that I can tell ( aka same corridor syndrome ) and you will get a good feeling of progression ( you can visually see getting closer to your goal). The enemies look nice but dont change much in the looks area but at least you dont get the same guy but his time hes red! Overall - Good looking game that helps to visually immerse you into the world.

Story and Setting : (Spoiler Free) The setting is an Island off the coast of Russia that has some dirty little secrets and as a US special forces soldier you have to infiltrate the island and find out what is going on. As a base story it is just like most of the other FPS games out there but Singularity adds a nice twist on the basic formula that makes it feel new and refreshing. Overall - The story wont break the bank on amazing plots but it will engage you very well and help to keep you playing to find out what happens next.

Gameplay : This is were the game really sets itself above a normal FPS. It has a slight rpg feel with upgradeable weapons and skill selecting although neither is a game changer or breaker. It has good gun play and the powers that you use are fun and work well but what this game does really well is that it lets you play the way you want to. No, there is no stealth or anything like that, it is all action and if something is in your way it has to die but the game gives you incredible freedom on how it dies.   You can play and complete this entire game with nothing but guns or once you get your powers you can complete the entire game with those. It never limits you and it gives you plenty of ammo or easily throwable items no matter which way you want to play. Overall - The gameplay is great and gives you a great feel of freedom that never tells you how you should play it

Replayability : While the story does give this game a little bit of replay ( you might want to play again just to see all the clues you didnt understand in the first playthrough ) and the gameplay lets you play it again in differnet ways, there is really no reason to play it more than a few times.

Personal overall enjoyment - This game was a good change of pace to me for normal FPS's. I enjoyed playing the game and was glad of the purchase I made. I will probably play it again sometime down the line and have no problem recommending it as a good game.

Join one AMERICAN man on his quest to become a time wizard who can cause death through willpower alone! It's Russian Call of Duty-Shock! Very linear, story that completely falls apart, but damn fun. Singularity would've been much better if it didn't take itself as seriously.

Your character is completely throw away, half of the other leads hardly do anything, and level design is hamfisted and forced. You get amazing guns, but you can't carry around the most original one (allows you to curve bullets in slow-mo). Nice items are placed in action sequence areas, forcing you to stop combat to collect them.

And yet the combat is gleeful. Every gun is ridiculously strong, but enemies still swarm well enough to make hard mode challenging. reviewText: A stripped down version of Bioshock, the game mechanics for using the time manipulation device to fight enemies and solve puzzles was actually quite fun. The story took a bit of a header near the end, and wasn't as dramatic or thematic as Bioshock, but in the realm of single player campaigns in shooters, this is one that actually merits the price of admission.

Much better than I expected. The atmosphere and environment of the game really draw you in and the story has its moments of greatness. Some pretty unique enemies and powers are a selling point for gameplay as well.

Some negatives would be that the player can get temporarily stuck on some objects and the first time it really became annoying was in a gameplay sequences where I had to run away, of all things. Another drawback is that some weapons seem to not phase enemies in regards to their approach/actions whereas others do.

All in all, I bougth the game for like 10$ awhile back and it's worth that price now even if I never come back and play it again (which I plan to).

From the get go it is obvious this is a straight up console port. The game doesn't support proper widescreen video resolutions and comes with some serious sound issues. When you get to actually playing the game you'll find the weapon selection lackluster, with a few exceptions. The upgrade functionality feels tacked on and many of the enemies are more annonyances than anything else. The time manipulation mechanic is okay, but I feel they could have done more with it. Multiplayer is a crapshoot and dead.

Even so, Singularity does have some redeeming qualities. The story is a real head spinner with 3 seperate endings; although which one you get has nothing to do with your actions throughout the game and instead comes down to one decision at the very end of the game. The plot will have you guessing to the end, and then some. Some of the set peices throughout the story are really amazing, and the boss fights stand out as high points.

Overall, I'd give it 5/10. Wait for an under 10$ sale

Okay. I am going to start this out by saying something: THIS IS A HORROR GAME.

I personally picked it up because I enjoy games with interesting twists, like using time in combat. Nowhere said that this game is scarey. It ♥♥♥♥ing is.

That said, lets review:

THE GOOD:
Time and combat work very well together, you can (once you get the right upgrades) slow/nearly stop time, blast people's legs, arms and heads off, age/reduce in age objects, people, and mutants, as well as shoot them up with a big ♥♥♥ shotgun, or whatever else you fancy.
If the game is meant to do horror, it does it well (for me), with various jumpscares that are very nicely implimented (ie. scare the ♥♥♥♥ out of you since you don't expect them), and the atmosphere is one of uncomfortable ruins.
The shooting works. You shoot people, if you shoot them enough, they die. The guns sound quite weak, which is normal for modern shooters, but people react to some extent when shot (especially with the shotgun)
Basic upgrade system for guns, with some customisation for your time powers, and various perks you can get.
New mechanics are added constantly through the game, so you never feel like your game is stagnating.
Although the game is completely linear in its story until the end (2 endings and a 'hidden' ending), there are plenty of areas to explore that can add 1-3 hours onto the game (its about 6 hours if you just follow the footsteps)

THE BAD
The plot is a little hard to follow at times, and there are some questions at the end I just want answering, and don't seem to be answered. I won't leave them here as they WILL spoil the game for you.
The AI is a little off. People with guns will generally either stay where they are (which is typically in the middle of a corridor with no cover) or just run to their set position and start firing. Mutants just run towards you on the shortest trajectory.
Not many bosses as such, only a couple of points where you meet more powerful mutants that are annoying to kill. To make up for that, you have a couple of timed RUN AWAY sequences. Yay.
One of the time powers is really annoying to set off, as it involves pressing the button for another power twice quickly, which rarely works. I guess this is probably a legacy from consoles, where you have about 8 buttons for everything.
The description on the store page isn't quite telling the truth. You do no 'travel seamlessly between 1955 and 2010'. The game pretty much orders you into a rift so you can go back in time, do something to alter the future, then go back into the present to carry on as normal. You don't get the choice of when you want to go back, you just have to.

The Ugly
The graphics are quickly aging, and not terribly gracefully.
Those mutants are not going to win any beauty contests any time soon.

Paranormal sci-fi horror with temporal-weaponry. 2nd playthrough. Definitely worth playing again. Story revolves around a newly discovered (ficticious) element, e99, and the island Katorga-12 where it is exclusively found. E99 holds enormous energetic potential, but is unstable, mutates organic life, and distorts time where it abounds. You are a captain in the u.s. military sent to the island; thought abandoned, to investigate an energy signature which is blinding u.s. spy satelittes. Upon arriving, a temporal wake engulfs you, sending you back in time to 1955. There you find yourself in the same lab facility as it burns. Without hesitation, you rescue a scientist, Demichev. Only before a 2nd temporal wake brings you back to 2010. Demichev was one of two lead scientists heading research into the element and its application. He will continue recklessly pursuing his controversial research without regard for life. His research results in the development and collapse of the singularity, it kills 1000s instantly and mutates any remaning survivors on the island. The result is a paranormal, atemporal mess, torn by violence. Failing to be disuaded, Demichev develops e99 weaponry and quickly rises to power, empowering Russia to conquer the world. The game is primarily about restoring the timeline, but throughout the game you encounter cryptic warnings, written in messages only you can reveal. Perhaps left by a future-you? or by MIR-12? A mysterious organization with knowlecge they couldn't possibly posess, and whose intentions are unclear. As far as enemies, the mutant survivors of the island, warped by the energy of singularity collapse are almost alien. They move incredibly fast, in and out of phase, or can teleport. Others have heightened hearing, but are blind. Still others have become incredibly large. Temporal rifts frequent the game where you can witness events in the past occuring concurrently with the present; revealing the tragic deaths of the inhabitants. Recordings also build this story and reveal what happened in the time since you traveled to 1955. Mostly detailing the exodus of survivors and their horrific deaths attempting to leave. Weapons are also e99 based. Guided rounds, sniper that can slow down time for precise shots, and standard-shooter semi-auto shotgun, assault rifle, and minigun. The most fun is with your TMD, a device you are led to early in the game which embues you with great power. You can create time manipulation fields that age/rejuvenate items or people/mutants, timelocks which freeze time, you can pull things between time-periods, and jump between the years 1955 and 2010. Futher more, you can unleash a blast of energy from your palm that will send enemies flying or will rip them apart. Graphics were out of date even for it's time, but it's just bloody fun to play. And the story line is eery, but enjoyable. Short, but worth your attention, especially if you're into paranormal or sci-fi horror games. Fans of the metro or STALKER series would enjoy, although the feel is much more arcade.

Let me preface this review by saying I waited 4 years to play this game. I liked the look of it when it released in 2010 but could never bring myself to buy it at full price. I picked it up on sale from Steam for about $8 and for that price is it probably worth it.

The Singularity isn't a bad game in any way but it relies to much on being derivative of it's peers and often makes the classic modern FPS mistake of using a brown color pallet and heavy industrial level design.

The shooting itself is good if not great, the enemies are varied (shades of Doom, Wolfenstein, Half Life and even COD can be seen here) and weapons and your TMD (read Half life 2 gravity gun mix with some other stuff) can be upgraded. Towards the end of the game you can do some really neat things with your TMD/weapon combos that keep combat fun and lively.

The story is a little convoluted and the characters are muddy. Much like the TMD rips off Half Life 2's gravity gun in some respects so the cast here are retreads of the characters in the older game. The female lead is a poor man's Alyx Vance but does a serviceable job guiding you through the story. I just had a hard time connecting with the characters, although I will say the multiple endings to the game is a nice touch!

The TMD does also allow for some minor puzzle elements that can initially seem taxing but once you have seen one of about the 3 or 4 puzzles that are used through the game you can quickly identify and solve them. In the end what strikes you as an “oh wow nice touch” trick the first time ends up feeling played about by the 25th.

This leads me onto my biggest gripe with the game: the level design. The Singularity has some amazing potential and wastes it utterly with brown industrial environ after brown industrial environ. The levels set in the past are, varied, bright, colorful and full of unique little touches that made me want to explore this cold war era lab (it really reminded me of half life 1, a living breathing facility I wanted to inhabit not just visit). It is a crying shame that you never visit them for more than 10 minutes at a time. These levels are also filled with Russian soliders that act half way intelligently and are fun to fight. The modern levels by contrast are by the numbers brown boxes that remind me of quake 1 or painkiller with less character. The enemies that inhabit them are varied and some are fun to fight but too many simply charge at you. Once you acquire some decent weapons and TMD upgrades they become a chore to fight.

The split between old and modern sums up the Singularity well for every good moment there is something dull and bland. A unique feature or moment here is followed by a dull 30 minute sepia section shortly after. If only Raven had stuck to using the 50's setting throughout the game we may have had a truly unique and classic game on our hands. It's still a decent shooter and well worth a blast through if you can get it for under $10 but I came away feeling happy I played it but sad that it wasn't as good as it could have been.

reviewText: Much better than seemed at first sight. The first hour may be boring but it becomes better, keep going. I was near to quitting in the first hour and I'm very happy I didn't.

Great game. I played it out in one sitting, which should say enough on its own. Singularity is basically a mix of Wolfenstein and Half-Life with an obvious flavor of Timeshift and some distinct Dead Space aftertastes.

It is a linear game, but it shines and confuses just enough to actually give you the ability to miss things because you wander down the corridor that you think is the 'side room' and it turns out to be the next section which prevents you from heading back. (The save points are killer for us completionists in that way.) The huge amount of world-building, be it through notes and projectors of varying kinds, or even the outright 'experience' as only a time-travel game can.. it all makes for a highly enjoyable and engaging experience.

My biggest complaint is probably the fact that whenever the game tosses you a special weapon with a 'you will need this', you know that you are in for a lot of pain. Not because of the crazy battles, but rather because those special weapons tend to be so damn awkward compared to more conventional stuff that I just keep dying when using them. Having been trained by those moments to love my regular weapons, I ended up specializing in my two favorites and avoided everything else like the plague. (I liked one or two other weapons too, but you can only carry two weapons with you, so why waste time and effort upgrading those other weapons?) Regardless, there is plenty of variety in the terrain allowing most of those weapons to find some times to shine, although actually having the right weapon in the right situation is a rarity outside of those moments where the game literally feeds you the gun in question. Throw in the ever developing time-related mechanics and it is definitely more than yet another shooter.

I'd probably give it a 9/10.

I wanted to play a game in which I shoot stuff. I also prefer my shooting games to have something quirky or fun or special to set them apart from all the other shooting games. I bought Singularity and it delivered, for the most part, at least.

Singularity is a very basic shooter. It's story is nothing really special (it's a very predictable time-traveling mess), the voice acting is standard, the guns are regular guns (except for the seeker, which the game occasionally hands you so you can have some fun) and the enemies are russians who shoot you and mutants that slash, punch and bite you.

So what sets this game apart?

The TIME MANIPULATION DEVICE! While the game occasionally seems to forget that the thing exists, and while the mechanics on which it operates (story-wise) are confusing as hell and while it's mostly just a gravity gun with a kill enemy" function
date: it DOES set Singularity apart from all the other shooters. An enemy giving you trouble? Age him/it to dust! A bunch of soldiers giving you trouble? Revert a couple of them into feral mutants and watch the madness. The TMD also allows for some fun puzzle design
recommended: which is a bonus as far as I am concerned.\n\nSingularity is not a long game and it's not the best game there is

Singularity had gotten my attention when it first came out, but I had to dismiss it because I lacked the skill to deal with the FPS genre. A few years later, with Borderlands 2 and Mass Effect under my belt, I found the game suggested in my steam queue, and purchased it the next time it went on sale. I was surprised to find that the game had aged well, and was solid.
The meat of the game is in the gameplay. Singularity takes a solid shooter base, and adds interesting time-manipulation mechanics to the combat. Enemies are varied and interesting, and different tactics are required to deal with them. The standard arsenal of pistol, machine gun, shotgun, and sniper rifle are augmented with a few other interesting and appropriately scifi weapons, which you can upgrade.
The setting is an island named Katorga-12, a secret soviet research facility. The levels are well designed, and full of personality. There are lots of notes to read, and audio recordings to give you a look into the history of the island. Little details all over the place create an immersive experience that encourages exploring every nook and cranny. Periodic puzzle sections provide a pleasant change of pace without being too difficult, and thinking with portals" (as it were) provides access to extra goodies.
That being said

The story was interesting and unique, despite the characters who you never really feel any attachment to.  A variety of weapons was nice to see, but the weapons system could've been better handeled--specifically the upgrades.  Rather than having upgrades to counter the weaknesses that the weapons all had, each weapon unfortunately all had the same upgrades of Clip Capacity (hold more ammo overall), Reload Speed, and Damage.  The system could've easily taken into account the charge factor for the railgun and decreased the amount of time that it took to charge, for instance, or it could've given the grenade launcher a higher range--different upgrades depending on the weapon, to overcome the respective weapon's weaknesses.  It was also nice to see a variety of enemies.\n\nThe overall singleplayer campaign is roughly 10 hours long, but it is an interesting game, and I certainly recommend it if you can overlook its flaws.  I'd give it an 8/10, only because of the seemingly lazy implementation of weapons upgrades (as opposed to character upgrades), and that they could've fleshed out the characters a bit more and made you actually feel some sort of sentiment or attachment to said characters.  Also, the suicide-bombing swarm bug enemies (I think they were called Phase Ticks).  Seriously, screw those guys.

For starters the game is a measly 5 hours long with little replay value. Yes the game dose have multiple endings but the game saves your progress right before your chose what ending you will get. My next problem is the difficulty. The game in my opinion was way to easy. The tmd made combat interesting but it also made you unstoppable. And the amount of medkits you get are insane. there were many times where i would pass up on 5 in one room because i was maxed out. I only died once and stood there and let 5 monsters chomp on me while i spun around. The few bosses that are there honestly just feel like normal enemies with giant ♥♥♥♥ me blisters on them. The only thing that stuck out in my mind was the weapon selection. you have your basics like a revolver, assault rifle, shotgun, and sniper rifle. But then you start getting guns like the spikeshot that is a railgun with a delay or a grenade launcher that has grenades that you can move on your own. However you are limited to two guns that you can carry except for super weapons. I went through most of the game with the assault rife as my primary for most of the game. and if the is a situation where you can use a gun to its fullest there is convinently a dead body with on laying right in front of you. The super weapons bring the most flavor to the table. The seeker fires an explosive round that you can control in a cool bullet time scene. And then there is a rocket launcher. Ok they may have run out of ideas at that point. The game is fun however and if you looking to kill some time (no pun intended) i recommend picking this game up only on a sale though.

story has many loopholes and leaves you with so many questions
StoryThe story has a lot of potential in this game, and I'd say they pull of the story about halfway into the game. After that a lot of things start to happen kinda without explanation. So I strongly feel that this game was rushed at the end and that the game kinda suffered for it, this is something I will come back to several times in this review.

CharactersYou yourself is much like a Gordon Freeman, voiceless and even faceless in this game. I honestly think this is a bit of a shame, they could have made the story more intriguing and interesting if they character you were playing had feelings and thoughts on the situation. The other characters are pretty standard. There's the good guy, bad guy and the cute girl, these are the three NPC characters you interact with pretty much. They're not well written and you don't care about them but they do their part. Perhaps if the game wasn't rushed this wouldn't have happened.

enemies, weapons and powersThe enemy design is really cool in this game, the monsters are scary, gross and challenging to kill. They do lack a bit of variety so you won't see to many different kind of enemies. But the game isn't super long so it's okay. In between fighting monsters you will be shooting at Russians, they are standard NPC's with guns, not much to discuss there.

The weapons in this game feel great, look great feel very balanced. The problem I have with them is that there are like 6-7 weapons in total at the end of the game, and I only touched the first three because the others were just introduced to damn late and you have already spent so much upgrade points on the early weapons that it doesn't feel worth it switching to the new ones, this might be a side effect of the game being rushed as well. The weapon upgrade system leaves a lot to wish for, each weapons needs 9 points to be fully upgraded. I'm not even sure if I find a total of 20 upgrade points through the whole game.

The powers are probably what carries this game, You have a device on your arm with lets you age specific objects in the world, stop time in an area, levitate and throw objects (kinda like HL2 gravity gun). It's just a ton of fun and the effects look fantastic. They come up with some interesting puzzles with it as well.

Difficulty and upgradesMuch like most games this game lets you choose between easy, medium and hard difficulty. I tried normal on my first play-through and I honestly don't think I died a single time. I'm now playing it again on hard and I still have a very easy time. I can play through some parts without any problem and then die seven times in a row in the next area, so the difficulty level feels a bit unbalanced.

You can also purchase upgrades for you character and your gravity gun" in this game

This is without a doubt one if the best games I have played in years, though it has some quirks" that are typical to ported games.

The good
The story is extremely well done
date: with excellent voice acting and animation. Combat is fluid and frantic but is not constant nor does it swamp all other aspects of the game. There are plenty of moments to just look around and feel the atmosphere of the game which really allows for deep immersion. The slower moments in the game are dotted with some very good and logical puzzles that you must solve to advance or solve to reach a hidden area.\nThe absolute best part of the game is the blend of visual and audio aspects to put you into the most tense condition that I can recall while playing any game.\nThough it does have the thrice cursed "Boss Monsters" It includes them in such a fluid manner and rather than just throwing you into an arena with a monster that you have no clue what the "super secret" way to defeat it could be

but with a story this good I would have loved to stay in it a while longer.
There are a few places that the collision actually blocks the path you are suppsed to follow in such a way as to make you think it is another invisible wall. Here i would like to note that I HATE invisible walls!! When you make a barrier it should look like a barrier not like an open path that might lead to a hidden area.
The controls suffer from being ported over from a game deck so they do not really mesh well with keyboard and mouse but it is not too bad and you can remap them to more fit you preferences which helps a lot.
There are several places in the tutorial section of the game that gloss over some things that you really need to know so it's very easy to miss which makes using the equipment later in game more difficult than it should.

Over all this is a beautiful gem of a game that I think anyone who is a fan of tense and dark gameplay should absolutely pick up

Alternative history games I feel generally fall into two categories; absurdly grim alterno-dramas that take themselves too serviously, and the nonsensical cheese fests that know its a silly parody. Its a premise that can go both ways in quality. Singularity treads a good balance in melodrama and campiness, and offers up a decent shooter.

Story is your standard Cold War 'what would happened if'. 1950's Russians discover an all powerful, time distorting element E99 (not to be confused with Einsteinium) on a remote island, experiments go horribly wrong and left to stew for fifty years, and a botched American black ops mission changes the timeline and basically gives Russia the world, and you have to jump back and forth to fix the present/future. There have been better plots in games, but this isn't a totally laughable B movie. It is forunate that the games atmosphere saves it from B movie hilarity. Being trapped inside a decaying, direlict research complex greatly enhances the overall mood and plot of Singulariy, adding a mounting sense of dread and horror that; at least for me, was almost too much to handle.

Singularity's gameplay is pretty competent; starting off as your traditional FPS with generous doses of action survivor horror thrown in for good measure. It shortly becomes what I can only discribe as a 50's sci fi shooter with the introduction of the Time Manipulation Device, a powerful wristband that let you age and revert certain objects and enemies at will, it is perhaps not as solid as Half Life's Gravity Gun. But its still pretty fun. The guns you find throughout are varied and not half bad, but as you find your formula to fight Mutants and Russian soldiers, you'll find yourself using and upgrading only a combination of three or four for everything. Finally there is a lot of variety to them, some of them are not the smartest AI's I've seen; But some, like the mutants that shift in and out of the material world, are unnervingly tough to deal with.

Singularity is a little rough around the edges, but at the end of day its a very satisifing shooter. It does a worthly job of blending its story, atmosphere and game mechanics into something I found memorable and be more willing to replay some day. And in an Era of throw away military shooters, that is saying something.

Short, kinda cheesy in terms of voice acting and plot as most linear single player FPS games usually are but that is overshadowed by the epic and high quality mechanics this game has. I wouldn't suggest getting it unless it was on Sale simply because the game is quite old and based on that fact alone that's why I say it doesn't deserve full price, but would it have been worth full price when it first game out? Probably.

In this game you are Captain Renko, a US Army Operative who is sent with a team to Katorga-12. An island just off the coast of Russia. Whilst there events occur and you end up changing the course of history and finding a device by the name of the TMD, or the Time Manipulation Device (Creative. I know). On the Island of Katorga-12 a revolutionary resource used in many technologies throughout the island and is the basis of the island having any sort of presence at all, and that resource is E99. It is what powers the TMD. When E99 is applied to something, be it an object or a living creature/person, adverse effects happen and the TMD was created to channel that.

PROS:

The TMD (Time Manipulation Device) is something that sticks with you as an item all throughout the game. Occasional upgrade related to plot events means it always has a relatively fair balance against the enemies you will encounter at different porions of the game. You'll get to use it to turn back or advance time on an object in the world to do a number of things. One of those things is aging and then restoring objects to open shutter gates which are there halting your progress to continue the game, or (IMO) more importantly to find hidden goodies such as the fairly rare Weapon Upgrade Kits and also more of the much wanted E99 Technology.

Atmosphere Is pretty good, best in the first part of the game but it does end up being non-existent in some places but revives again eventually only to die out again. Atmostphere is worthy to be listed as both a pro and a con simply because of it's inconsistency.

Weapons are basic, and small in range but they offer enough variety to turn a linear experience in to something worthwhile I'd say.

Mechanics include the TMD to manipulate and manage the flow of time in real-time, which I explain more about in the original paragrapth about the TMD.

An upgrade system for the TMD, you as an individual via perks and also the weapons via upgrade kits. With E99 Technology as currency in this to be used at upgrade stations and weapon lockers to get health, ammo and upgrades as I just mentioned. The mechanics in this aren't very in-depth but they do exist and are pretty solid, solid enough to say they're a pro rather than a con.

CONS:

Characters, whilst thankful they exist they lack depth of any sort, they're stereotypical, sometimes useless, feels like they're was supposed to be more to them but no one bothered to add those things. The range of actual characters is very small and like most if not all other Linear FPS shooters, you don't actually Speak" to characters but moreso you are simply told things by them

Singularity is a fun little romp about time manipulation and travel on an old WWII Russian island base.  It has overtones of Bioshock (scientific utopianism), Fallout (1955 environments and retro-tech) and a good chunk of Resident Evil (monsters).

The music isn't anything fancy, and there are no subtitles.  The graphics hold up very well for a six year old game.  I did run into a couple of bugs, but nothing bad or a simple reload didn't fix.

The game is labeled as survival horror.  This is not correct.  It's action horror, simply because it is almost impossible to die unless you're just bad at games.  By no stretch of the imagination is the game difficult, as it practically throws medpacks and boxes of ammunition at every available opportunity.

This is, of course, not including the Time Manipulation Device and its various abilities.  With it, an otherwise average corridor shooter is spiced up with some simple time puzzles and incredibly overpowered battle mechanics.  It pretty much breaks the game, but it's enough fun that you don't really mind.

I didn't play any multiplayer.  From what I understand, it was great, but dead seeing as how old it is.

There are reasonably large upgrade systems for both the TMD and your guns.  Unfortunately, there is no NG+, which is kind of a bummer seeing as how there are technically four different endings.  From reading the other ones, I hesitate to call any of the endings good"
date: with the primary choice being kind of a letdown.  There's room for a sequel
recommended: but it'll never happen because Activision liquidated Raven Software as soon as the game was done.\n\nDon't pay more than $15 for it and you won't regret it."

Dear sir/madam. I am writing to return the enclosed 'Time Manipulation Device' I purchased as part of your first-person shoot-them-up 'Singularity'. I had looked forward to using the tool to rend the fabric of spacetime like a cheap hooker's tights, but was confused by the results. When assailed by a spindly mutant, for example, I found my TMD simply caused him to turn red, inflate, run towards me and explode – at some cost to my constitution. How is this related to time manipulation? I fail to see how the mutated gentleman could have been an about-to-explode gentleman at any point preceding our encounter – nor destined to become one after it.

Furthermore, while I see consistently good results using the device to age crates and staircases, it has no effect on doors. I did read your helpful disclaimer that the device could only affect objects infused with Element 99, but this only raises further questions. What benefit did the Soviets imagine the most lethal chemical known to man would bring to the humble stair?

I hope for a refund and that you will rename the device The Certain Things Manipulator to save future customers the same confusion.

Yours faithfully,

Your Future Self Or Something Trippy Like That


In Singularity you're an American captain sent to investigate a remote Soviet outpost. What happens there changes history to put a powerhungry lunatic in charge of the world. His empire is based on the Singularity, a power source derived from dangerous new element E99. Ostensibly, E99 is the explanation for both your time manipulation abilities and the mutants you fight. More honestly, they might as well have called it Unexplainium.

The joke is that this is Raven's first original game in a decade, and it's comprised entirely of parcel tape and borrowed ideas. It's as if they've been collecting tropes to rip off: when they couldn't find a way to fit time travel into a Jedi Knight game, or exploding alien bugs into Wolfenstein, they put them into this. I don't mind the borrowing – more games should learn from what the classics do well – but the unfocused jumble they've ended up with makes a lot of the coolest ideas arbitrary or useless.

The Certain Things Manipulator is a perfect example. It's supposed to age things or renew them, which in most cases means bending spacetime to perform menial maintenance work, such as repairing decrepit staircases. It's used for one good puzzle, where you wedge a collapsed crate in a narrow space and renew it to widen the gap. But rather than build on that puzzle type, they simply repeat it four or five times and never come up with anything else.

Even true time-travel isn't used for anything interesting. I thought for one exciting moment that I had to use a crate to jam a bulkhead door open in the past, so it would remain open when I hopped back to the future. But no. You just have to take the crate itself to 2010 and stand on it to reach a higher ledge.

Then you start using the CTM on enemies, and the jumble of random mechanics you find is almost funny. Some enemies it ages. Some it swells to twice their size. Some it turns into zombies who vomit acid on their friends. And some, as mentioned, simply turn red and explode.

The thing is, turning people into projectile-vomiting zombies is awesome. If the device always did something along those lines, it'd be a fun and inventive cornerstone of combat. Instead, even towards the end of the game, it takes a second to remember which arbitrary effect your CTM will have on the enemy type you're facing.

One idea that's close to working is the stasis field: you can throw out an orb that pauses everything in a generous sphere of influence. It's awkward, thanks to using the same key as your rudimentary gravity gun, but it offers some interesting options. Lacking any long-range weapons, I was about to give up fighting a sniper when I tried firing a freezeball at him. It hit some cover between us, but every shot he fired was caught in the field and held there, while I slipped round it and shotgunned him at close range.

More commonly, it provides breathing room to fuss around with the game's tactics. You can pick up and fling both exploding barrels and freeze canisters that turn enemies rigid and brittle. You can pump bullets into a stasis field and they'll all hit at once when it collapses. And you can manually roll grenades around in a murderous game of Marble Madness. None of these things are quicker or more efficient than shooting people with guns, but stopping everyone with a stasis field gives you time to do them anyway.

You can eventually level-up your abilities, including the size and duration of your stasis field. But 'eventually' is a dangerous word in a seven-hour game. You get enough E99-themed experience points to make customisations, but most of these are locked until you find certain scraps of paper. It's only in the last hour or so that you have any real freedom to upgrade yourself and, shortly after that, you're given infinite energy for your CTM. I'd specialised in maximising that, so all my upgrades were a waste of time. Sulk mode activate.

The other problem with the level-up stuff is that you get a lot of experience points by exploring. This isn't a nice game to explore. Apart from dragging you through some miserably drab takes on Ruined Lab, Anonymous Warehouse and Thing That Might Be A Sewer, it's riddled with invisible barriers. Can you jump on that? NO. Can you get through there? NO. Can you get across- NO.

The scenery isn't helped by a problem where low-detail versions of most surfaces don't get sharper when you get close. It looks like the world's been hosed down with a number of increasingly beige flavours of soup. That the developers missed this hints at something gone badly wrong behind the scenes.

What did happen behind the scenes, surprisingly, is a whole lot of effort, love and intelligence on the multiplayer. A feature that's so often rushed, in a game that clearly has been rushed, yet it's packed with far more ideas than it strictly needed – all done well. It's a class-based humans vs mutants deathmatch, with an objective-based mode to focus the action. So having a random jumble of unrelated abilities actually works here: each human class has only one or two of your singleplayer powers, and each mutant has a radically different way of fighting.

My favourite's the Phase Tick: a tiny insect that can walk on walls and ceilings, explode on people, or jump on a human's face to take them over. At that point you simply become the player you face-hugged, only with lethal friendly fire. Great fun to do, and even oddly fun to fight against: as a human, I respawned once to face my tick-possessed doppelganger – who promptly killed me with my own carefully chosen loadout.

I'm not optimistic that there'll be many people to play against in the long run – there's no server browser, and already the matchmaking is struggling to find me a game. But it's another aspect to Singularity that makes me sad the overall game was bungled. It just needed someone to say, halfway through development, “Good work guys, now pick three or four mechanics that really work, make them consistently useful, design a few more puzzles around them – and cut everything else.”

It would have given them time to do something interesting with time travel, the space to give each ability its own key (currently four keys double up), and scope to make the combat creative and satisfying throughout. What we've got instead is a desperately muddled game that's routinely frustrating to play, but one that copies enough cool stuff to be fun every ten minutes or so. If it drops to a pittance on Steam, it's worth your time.

Singularity is a fun little romp about time manipulation and travel on an old WWII Russian island base.  It has overtones of Bioshock (scientific utopianism), Fallout (1955 environments and retro-tech) and a good chunk of Resident Evil (monsters).

The music isn't anything fancy, and there are no subtitles.  The graphics hold up very well for a six year old game.  I did run into a couple of bugs, but nothing bad or a simple reload didn't fix.

The game is labeled as survival horror.  This is not correct.  It's action horror, simply because it is almost impossible to die unless you're just bad at games.  By no stretch of the imagination is the game difficult, as it practically throws medpacks and boxes of ammunition at every available opportunity.

This is, of course, not including the Time Manipulation Device and its various abilities.  With it, an otherwise average corridor shooter is spiced up with some simple time puzzles and incredibly overpowered battle mechanics.  It pretty much breaks the game, but it's enough fun that you don't really mind.

I didn't play any multiplayer.  From what I understand, it was great, but dead seeing as how old it is.

There are reasonably large upgrade systems for both the TMD and your guns.  Unfortunately, there is no NG+, which is kind of a bummer seeing as how there are technically four different endings.  From reading the other ones, I hesitate to call any of the endings good"
date: with the primary choice being kind of a letdown.  There's room for a sequel
recommended: but it'll never happen because Activision liquidated Raven Software as soon as the game was done.\n\nDon't pay more than $15 for it and you won't regret it."

This game is a pretty amazing single player experience. While it is not completely innovative, it brings some new ideas to the genre, and still stands as its own game. I love the plot, all of the creepy moments, and the amazing atmosphere. I dare say this game is almost as good as Metro 2033 in terms of atmosphere. Finally, the end wraps everything up nicely and allows you to choose one of four endings, but since the game uses checkpoints, you do not need to replay the game to see all of the endings. However, the game lacks achievements that the console versions have; it's not a big deal, but it would have been a nice touch to add to replayability. As it stands, there is virtually no replayability value, unless you simply want to play through it on a harder difficulty.

Singularity is a game about war and time travel, but it isn't a generic rebrand on the story like a lot of other games centered around war and time travel in the genre are. The game is centered around an American soldier who gains control of a time manipulation device, more commonly known as the T.M.D. and changes the history as well as the future in his mission to save the world from a rip in time called a singularity.

Pros:Rich in story
Lots of weapons
T.M.D. is a wonderful weapon/feature
Nice list of characters and development of characters
Cool WW2 era art style
Good story/plot development
Lots of locations to explore throughout the world
Cons:Extremely short game
Kind of hard story to follow
Repetitive enemy spawns/types nearer to end game
Somewhat linear at points
This game is a ton of fun for the money I paid for it (got it on a Steam sale) and the story is worth it. I think the game would benefit from more play time and a less linear expierence.
7.5 The game is fun, and it well worth playing, but seeing how short the game is and the repetitiveness of some of the enemies near end game, I think the score is justified.

3.) Listen to scientist and go back in time and kill yourself (fixes the timeline, but you die because the scientist ♥♥♥♥ed up and told you the wrong things to fix the singularity)

4.) Kill both the scientist and the dictator and live your life in solitude until later... (this in my opinion is the best ending becuase you fix the timeline, end the scientist so that he can't use the T.M.D. to control people, you kill the dictator so that he can't use the T.M.D. to spread his rule and communism, you fix the singularity, and finally you get to keep the T.M.D. and later come to rule what we now know as America)
